clinical_study.brief_title: Fetal ST Segment and T Wave Analysis in Labor
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Trial of Fetal ECG ST Segment and T Wave Analysis as an Adjunct to Electronic Fetal Heart Rate Monitoring (STAN)

lead_sponsor.agency: The George Washington University Biostatistics Center

collaborator.agency: Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

clinical_study.source: The George Washington University Biostatistics Center

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research is to test a new instrument, called a fetal STAN monitor, that may be used during labor to monitor the electrical activity of the baby's heart. This new instrument is designed to help the doctor determine how well the baby is doing during labor. It will be used along with the existing electronic fetal monitor used to measure the baby's heart rate and the mother's contractions during birth. The specific purpose of this research study is to see if this new instrument (fetal STAN monitor) will have an impact on newborn health.

detailed_description.textblock:
A Randomized Trial of Fetal ECG ST Segment and T Wave Analysis as an Adjunct to Electronic Fetal Heart Rate Monitoring (STAN):
Fetal ECG analysis of the ST segment (STAN) is now FDA-approved and clinically available in the United States as an adjunct for the interpretation of electronic fetal heart rate patterns. There have been a number of randomized controlled trials as well as observational studies in Europe documenting utility of this modality in terms of reducing fetal acidosis at birth, and decreasing the need for operative vaginal delivery. However, despite these endorsements, there remain concerns with the application of the technology to the United States. None of the randomized trials were performed in the United States where patient case-mix and obstetrical practice, such as the use of fetal scalp pH, differ from Europe, which may affect the impact of this technology on perinatal outcomes. Moreover, the results of the European studies are not uniformly positive.
This protocol describes a randomized controlled trial of the STAN technology as an adjunct to electronic fetal heart rate monitoring versus fetal heart rate monitoring alone.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: The study is a randomized, controlled clinical trial of 11,000 women in labor at > 36.0 weeks gestation randomized to one of two groups using the STAN S31 system: Fetal STAN electrode inserted and data available to caregivers (open device group) Fetal STAN electrode inserted, but data masked to the caregivers (masked device group)
study_design_info.masking_description: The study is a randomized, controlled clinical trial of 11,000 women in labor at > 36.0 weeks gestation randomized to one of two groups using the STAN S31 system: Fetal STAN electrode inserted and data available to caregivers (open device group) Fetal STAN electrode inserted, but data masked to the caregivers (masked device group)

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Primary Composite Outcome
primary_outcome.time_frame: From Delivery through 1 month of age
primary_outcome.description: Composite primary outcome of intrapartum fetal death, neonatal death, Apgar score <=3 at 5 minutes, neonatal seizure, umbilical artery blood pH <= 7.05 with base deficit >=12 mmol/L in extra-cellular fluid, intubation for ventilation at delivery, neonatal encelphalopathy

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Intrapartum Fetal Deaths (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.time_frame: During labor and through delivery of the baby
primary_outcome.description: Death of the fetus during the intrapartum period.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Neonatal Deaths (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: Death of the newborn between delivery and1 month of age

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants With Apgar Score < = 3 at 5 Minutes (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score. The lowest score is 0, the highest score is 10.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants Who Experienced Neonatal Seizure (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: Number of infants who experienced Neonatal Seizure

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants With Umbilical-artery Blood pH < = 7.05 and Base Deficit in Extracellular Fluid > = 12 mmol/Liter (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: Umbilical-artery blood pH < = 7.05 and base deficit in extracellular fluid > = 12 mmol/liter

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Neonates Intubated for Ventilation at Delivery (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: Neonatal intubation for ventilation in the delivery room

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants Experiencing Neonatal Encephalopathy (Primary Outcome Component)
primary_outcome.description: Neonatal encephalopathy experienced between delivery and discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants by Delivery Method
secondary_outcome.description: Method of delivery of the baby: spontaneous, vacuum assisted, forceps, cesarean

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants by Indication for Cesarean
secondary_outcome.time_frame: At any time from randomization through delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With an Indication for Forceps or Vacuum Delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Indication for delivery by forceps or vacuum
Duration of labor in hours after randomization through delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Neonates With Shoulder Dystocia During Delivery
secondary_outcome.description: Presence of shoulder dystocia during delivery

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Any time from Randomization through Delivery

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Who Had a Postpartum Blood Transfusion
secondary_outcome.description: Blood transfusion from delivery and through hospital stay until discharge

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Experiencing Postpartum Endometritis

secondary_outcome.time_frame: From admission to labor and delivery through hospital discharge
secondary_outcome.description: Days of stay in the hospital

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants Admitted to Special Care Nursery
secondary_outcome.description: Intermediate care nursery or neonatal intensive care (anything more than well-baby nursery)

The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of Infants With Meconium Aspiration Syndrome
Number of Infants With a Major Congenital Malformation

arm_group.description: • Fetal STAN monitor electrode inserted and data available to caregivers
•Fetal STAN monitor electrode inserted, but data masked to the caregivers

intervention.description: The STAN monitor is a system for fetal surveillance that displays the FHR, the uterine activity and information resulting from the analysis of the ST segment of the fetal ECG.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Singleton, cephalic pregnancy
- Gestational age at least 36 weeks, 1 day
- Cervical dilation of at least 2 cm and no more than 7 cm
- Ruptured membranes
Exclusion Criteria:
- Multifetal gestation
- Planned cesarean delivery
- Need for immediate delivery
- Absent variability or sinusoidal pattern at any time, or a Category II fetal heart rate pattern with absent variability in the last 20 minutes before randomization
- Inability to obtain or maintain an adequate signal within 3 trials of electrode placements
- Occurrence of any ST event during attempt to obtain adequate signal
- Patient pushing in the first stage of labor
- Known major fetal anomaly or fetal demise
- Previous uterine surgery
- Placenta previa on admission
- Maternal fever greater than or equal to 38 C or 100.4 F
- Active HSV infection
- Known HIV or hepatitis infection
- Other maternal and fetal contraindications for using the STAN monitor
- Enrollment in another labor study
- Participation in this trial in a previous pregnancy
- No certified or authorized provider available

patient_data.ipd_description: The dataset will be shared per NIH policy after the completion and publication of the main analyses. Requests for datasets can be sent to mfmudatasets@bsc.gwu.edu

group.title: Open Group
group.description: S31 monitors in the open mode displayed ECG ST-segment information intended for use when uncertain fetal heart-rate patterns were detected. Management of the labor and delivery for women in this group was dictated by the ST-segment analysis guidelines

group.title: Masked Group
group.description: The masked S31 monitors functioned as conventional electronic fetal heart-rate monitors. The care of patients in the masked group was managed at the discretion of the attending physician or midwife.

group.title: Open Group
group.description: S31 monitors in the open mode displayed ECG ST-segment information intended for use when uncertain fetal heart-rate patterns were detected. Management of the labor and delivery for women in this group was dictated by the ST-segment analysis guidelines

group.title: Masked Group
group.description: The masked S31 monitors functioned as conventional electronic fetal heart-rate monitors. The care of patients in the masked group was managed at the discretion of the attending physician or midwife.

group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Number of Infants With Apgar Score < = 3 at 5 Minutes (Primary Outcome Component)
outcome.description: The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score. The lowest score is 0, the highest score is 10.

measure.description: The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score. analysis.p_value_desc: The p value was calculated based on the entire study cohort.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With an Indication for Forceps or Vacuum Delivery
outcome.description: Indication for delivery by forceps or vacuum

group.title: Open Group
group.description: S31 monitors in the open mode displayed ECG ST-segment information intended for use when uncertain fetal heart-rate patterns were detected. Management of the labor and delivery for women in this group was dictated by the ST-segment analysis guidelines

group.title: Masked Group
group.description: The masked S31 monitors functioned as conventional electronic fetal heart-rate monitors. The care of patients in the masked group was managed at the discretion of the attending physician or midwife.

measure.title: Number of Participants With an Indication for Forceps or Vacuum Delivery
measure.description: Indication for delivery by forceps or vacuum

outcome.title: Number of Participants Who Had a Postpartum Blood Transfusion
outcome.description: Blood transfusion from delivery and through hospital stay until discharge

group.title: Open Group
group.description: • Fetal STAN monitor electrode inserted and data available to caregivers fetal STAN monitor: The STAN monitor is a system for fetal surveillance that displays the FHR, the uterine activity and information resulting from the analysis of the ST segment of the fetal ECG.

group.title: Masked Group
group.description: •Fetal STAN monitor electrode inserted, but data masked to the caregivers fetal STAN monitor: The STAN monitor is a system for fetal surveillance that displays the FHR, the uterine activity and information resulting from the analysis of the ST segment of the fetal ECG.

measure.title: Number of Participants Who Had a Postpartum Blood Transfusion
measure.description: Blood transfusion from delivery and through hospital stay until discharge

outcome.title: Median Apgar Score at 5 Minutes
outcome.description: The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score.

measure.title: Median Apgar Score at 5 Minutes
measure.description: The Apgar score is a simple method of quickly assessing the health and vital signs of a newborn baby created by and named after Dr. Virginia Apgar. Apgar testing assesses Appearance, Pulse, Grimace and Activity in a newborn and is typically done at one and five minutes after a baby is born, and it may be repeated at 10, 15, and 20 minutes if the score is low. The five criteria are each scored as 0, 1, or 2 (two being the best), and the total score is calculated by then adding the five values obtained. Agar scores of 0-3 are critically low, 4-6 are below normal, and indicate that the baby likely requires medical intervention, scores of 7+ are considered normal. The lower the Apgar score, the more alert the medical team should be to the possibility of the baby requiring intervention. Some components of the Apgar score are subjective, and there are cases in which a baby requires urgent medical treatment despite having a high Apgar score.

reported_events.time_frame: Data on adverse events was collected on a continuous basis for each participant from the time of randomization up through the time of hospital discharge.

event.description: From site of fetal ECG clip

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There IS an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

point_of_contact.organization: The George Washington University Biostatistics Center
